content.question: Two objects, A and B, move toward one another. Object A has twice the mass and half the speed of object B. Which of the following describes the forces the objects exert on each other when they collide and provides the best explanation?

choices.label: The force exerted by A on B will be twice as great as the force exerted by B on A, because A has twice the mass of B.
The force exerted by A on B will be half as great as the force exerted by B on A, because A has half the speed of B.
The forces exerted by each object on the other are the same, because the product of mass and speed is the same for both objects.
The forces exerted by each object on the other are the same, because interacting objects cannot exert forces of different magnitude on each other.

content.answer: The forces exerted by each object on the other are the same, because interacting objects cannot exert forces of different magnitude on each other.
